1.text: It happened on one of those days, as he was teaching the people in the temple and preaching the Good News, that the priests and scribes came to him with the presbyters.

2.text: They asked him, “Tell us: by what authority do you do these things? Who is giving you this authority?”

3.text: He answered them, “I too will ask you one question. Tell me:

4.text: the baptism of John, was it from heaven, or from men?”

5.text: They discussed it among themselves, saying, “If we say, ‘From heaven,’ he will reply, ‘Why then did not you believe him?’

6.text: But if we say, ‘From men,’ all the people will stone us because they are convinced that John was a prophet.”

7.text: So they answered that they did not know where it was from.

8.text: Then Jesus said to them, “Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.”

9.text: He began to tell the people this parable. “A certain man planted a vineyard, and rented it out to some farmers, and went into another country for a long time.

10.text: At the proper season, he sent a slave to the farmers to collect his share of the fruit of the vineyard. But the farmers beat the servant and sent him away with nothing.

11.text: The owner then sent to them yet another slave, and they also beat him, treated him with contempt, and sent him away empty.

12.text: He sent yet a third [servant], and they also wounded him, and threw him out.

13.text: Then the lord of the vineyard thought, ‘What shall I do? I will send my beloved son! It may be that seeing him, they will respect him.’

14.text: But when the farmers saw him, they reasoned among themselves, saying: ‘This is the heir! Come, let us kill him, so that the inheritance may be ours.’

15.text: So, they threw him out of the vineyard, and killed him. Now what will the lord of the vineyard do to them?

16.text: He will come and destroy these farmers, and he will give the vineyard to others.” When the people heard this, they exclaimed, “May it never be!”

17.text: But Jesus looked at them and said, “Then what is this that is written:  ‘The stone which the builders rejected   Has become the chief cornerstone?’

18.text: Everyone who falls on that stone will be broken to pieces,   and it will crush to dust whoever it falls on.

19.text: The chief priests and the scribes were looking for a way to lay hands on him that very hour, but they feared the people because they knew that he spoke parables against them.

20.text: They watched him and sent out spies who pretended to be righteous in order to trap him in something he might say, so that they might hand him over to the power and authority of the governor.

21.text: They asked him, “Teacher, we know that you say and teach what is right, and that you are not partial to anyone but truly teach the way of God.

22.text: Is it lawful for us to pay taxes to Caesar, or not?”

23.text: But Jesus perceived their trickery and said to them, “Why are you testing me?

24.text: Show me a denarius! Whose image and inscription are on it?” They answered, “Caesar’s.”

25.text: So Jesus said to them, “Then give to Caesar what belongs to Caesar, and [give] to God what belongs to God!”

26.text: And they were not able to ensnare him in his words before the people. They marveled at his answer and remained silent.

27.text: Some of the Sadducees came to him, those who say there is no resurrection.

28.text: They asked him, “Teacher, Moses wrote to us that if a man dies having a wife and he dies without children, his brother should take the wife and raise up a posterity for his brother.

29.text: There were therefore seven brothers: the first took a wife and died childless.

30.text: The second took her as wife, and he [also] died childless.

31.text: The third took her, and likewise all seven [brothers] left no children and died.

33.text: Therefore, in the resurrection, whose wife is she? For the seven had her as wife.”

34.text: Jesus answered and said to them, “The children of this age get married and are given in marriage.

35.text: But those who are considered worthy to attain to that age and to the resurrection from the dead do not marry or are given in marriage.

36.text: They cannot die any more, because they are like the angels, and they are children of God, being children of the resurrection.

37.text: But that the dead are raised, even Moses showed in the [story of the burning] bush, when he called the Lord ‘The God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.’

38.text: Now he is not the God of the dead, but of the living, because all are alive to him!”

39.text: Some of the scribes answered, “Teacher, you speak well!”

40.text: After that, they did not dare to ask him any more questions.

41.text: Jesus asked them, “Why do they say that the Christ is David’s son?

42.text: David himself says in the book of Psalms,  ‘The Lord said to my Lord,   Sit at my right hand,

43.text: until I make your enemies the footstool of your feet.’

44.text: David therefore calls him Lord, so how is he his son?”

45.text: While all the people were listening, Jesus said to his disciples,

46.text: “Beware of the scribes who like to walk in long robes and who love greetings in the marketplaces, the best seats in the synagogues, and the best places at feasts.

47.text: They devour the houses of widows and for a pretense say long prayers: they will receive greater condemnation!”
